title: Are there photographs of Miyamoto Musashi? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, there aren’t any photographs of him because he lived in the 16th and 17th centuries. I encourage you to use google next time because questions like this can be answered in less than a minute and is a lot more convenient for you. There are photographs of samurai in the 19th century.      Surprisingly a woman samurai too. I knew women did fight in Japan but this was still surprising.   Notice that we see mail armor in these photos too. It was in fact used in Japan despite what some might tell you. Though it was certainly rarer.

Cameras didn’t exist around Musashi’s time, so the closest approximation would have to be sumi-e paintings. Mind you, there’s no guarantee that there won’t be embellishments, but it’s probably as close as you can get if you don’t have photography. The only way we’ll know for sure how he looked would be to find his bones, and then use a scanner to help make a forensic portrait of him.
There were no cameras when he lived. There are paintings however. This is from Reigando. The cave in Kumamoto where he wrote is book.
No. This wasn’t because he was camera shy but he lived in a time that was before cameras. There may be drawings of him though that’s probably the best that you’ll get.
His picture is not available because he was born and died before cameras were invented. However, there are a plenty of Miyamoto depictions: See: 宮本武蔵 - Google Search
No. Miyamoto Musashi lived in the 16th. and 17th. century. Photography wasn’t invented until the mid 19th. century.
